page.title: 01FELTWELL ANCHOR
page.content: A very flat district, some of it below sea level, now intensively farmed. The area forms part of the 'Black Fen', where the soils are derived from peat laid down when the water level was higher than it is now. Formerly used for grazing and fuel cutting, improvements in drainage made this some of the most productive land in Britain. Today a population of about 50 people work almost exclusively on the land. Some holdings are in the hands of large institutions, while others are owner occupied. Some land is owned by the Sir Edmund De Moundeford Trust in Feltwell and there are also some County Council smallholdings.
